page.title: 02CHANGING LANDSCAPE,HOCKLIFFE
page.content: In{William the Conqueror's 1086 {Domesday Survey}the land of{Hockliffe} was mainly an{arable}area with pasture lying along side the numerous streams. Early{14th century}records also show a great predominance of{arable}over meadow or permanent pasture. This picture of mainly an{arable}landscape continued in all for nearly{six {hundred years.} A change came in the early{17th {century}when the area was turned over almost entirely to{pasture}as grazing land for{cattle.} By the middle of the{20th century}the picture had changed again as many of the fields were given over to{arable {farming. }This trend appears to be continuing in the{1980s.}The effects of these recent agricultural changes have been to destroy much{Medieval {ridge and furrow landscape.}
